main event: On 6 May 1957 in Fargo, North Dakota, a round white object the size of a star at arm's length was observed for 40 minutes. The object moved from 030 degrees azimuth to 315 degrees before disappearing at the horizon.
interesting points: The object was observed for a lengthy duration of 40 minutes, allowing for detailed tracking.
The object's movement from 030 degrees azimuth to 315 degrees indicates a substantial change in direction and path.
The observation was classified as an Air-Visual type and was reported to have a varying path to the northwest before fading at the horizon.
The report states that the description, duration, flight path, and manner of disappearance suggest that the sighting was likely due to an aircraft.
The report also mentions that it was observed by a student at a high school in Fargo, North Dakota.
result: prozaic explanation - likely caused by an aircraft
witnesses: student at a high school in Fargo, North Dakota
